attributes.title: Experiment on Estimating Likelihood of Voter Fraud

q1.value: Experiment on Estimating Likelihood of Voter Fraud

q2.value: Lisa A. Bryant | Lonna R. Atkeson | Evan Crawford | Paul Gronke | Christopher Mann

q5.value: We would like to thank Reed College and the Democracy Fund for their ongoing support for our participation in the CCES, including this project., We would also like to thank Christopher B. Mann and Paul Manson for help with the development of the survey instrument.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This survey experiment tests whether geographic scope influences US citizens’ estimation of the likelihood of voter fraud occurring. Scholars and election officials estimate the incidence of voter fraud as vanishingly small, but a large proportion of the public continues to believe voter fraud is common. The public belief in voter fraud is driven by accusations of voter fraud made by political elites and covered by the news media. Scholars have investigated whether voters are confident ballots are counted as cast at various levels (own ballot, local, state, and national), and found notable differences in ballot confidence. However, there has been no direct investigation of where the public locates the occurrence of voter fraud. This experiment seeks to fill this gap in understanding of public attitudes about voter fraud. As part of the 2018 CCES Module for Reed College, respondents are first asked whether they personally observed vote fraud of various types. Then the experiment randomly assigns the respondents to estimate the likelihood that these same types of voter occur in either “the area where you live” or “somewhere in the country”. We expect significant differences in the public’s estimation of likelihood of voter fraud occurring locally (the area where you live) and nationally (somewhere in the country). The difference between these two treatments may be conditional on a several factors influencing the local environment. The experiment in the 2018 CCES Module for Reed College replicates an experiment in the 2012 CCES Module for the University of Miami. The 2012 research team is not involved in the 2018 experiment. One member of the 2018 research team (Mann) is able to access the 2012 CCES UMiami data for other research, but has not looked at these question prior to pre-registration. We use these two iterations of the experiment as a time series, especially with reference to potential for changes in opinion as public rhetoric about voter fraud and vote manipulation increased during and after the 2016 election.

q16.value: Treatments o Random assignment of wording in question about likelihood of voter fraud occuring between “the area where you live” or “somewhere in the country” o 50%-50% assignment between options o See pre-analysis plan for full treatment text Hypotheses - H1: The use of “the area where you live” or “somewhere in the country” will produce different outcomes. o H0: No difference between treatments o One tailed hypothesis: Prior belief that respondents will give a higher likelihood of each type of fraud occurring “somewhere in the country” vs. locally because familiarity/direct experience will reduce likelihood of believing fraud occurs locally. ▪ Similar to mechanism for higher confidence ballots that are counted as cast for local vs. national. Heterogeneity/moderator hypotheses - Hpersonal: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the respondent’s reporting of personally observing fraud (RCO440) o One tailed hypothesis: Smaller difference because people reporting fraud personally will be more likely to believe fraud occurs locally than those who don’t personally observe fraud. ▪ For those who report personally observing fraud, local fraud likelihood is still unlikely to exceed national fraud likelihood because these people will “see” fraud everywhere. - HTrump_supp: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the respondent’s support for President Trump. o President’s rhetoric will influence receptivity to framing ▪ HOBSV_Trump_supp: Trump supporters will assign higher likelihood of voter fraud occurring than non-supporters [observational hypothesis] o Two tailed experimental hypothesis: No directional expectation about whether difference will grow or shrink. ▪ Grow: Higher estimation of national occurrence of voter fraud while local remains stable ▪ Shrink: Larger increase in estimation of local occurrence of voter fraud among Trump supporters and/or ceiling on national occurrence among Trump supporters. - Hpartisan: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the respondent’s partisanship. o Difference in likelihood of fraud across treatments will vary with different parties due to differential exposure to news media and other discussions of voter fraud. o Test with 5 point party scale (see covariates below) o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. ▪ Some expectation that difference will be larger for Republicans for outcomes {1,3,4,5,6} and larger for Democrats for outcomes {2,3} - Hideology: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the respondent’s ideology. o Difference in likelihood of fraud across treatments will vary with different ideologies due to differential exposure to news media and other discussions of voter fraud o Test with 5 point ideology scale (see covariates below) o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. ▪ Some expectation that difference will be larger for conservatives for outcomes {1,3,4,5,6} and larger for liberals for outcomes {2,3} - Hstate_comp: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the competitiveness of statewide elections in the respondent’s state. o One tailed hypothesis: Smaller difference between treatments for respondents in areas with competitive elections due to higher estimates of likelihood of local fraud. - Hcong_comp: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the competitiveness of the Congressional election in the respondent’s US House district. o One tailed hypothesis: Smaller difference between treatments for respondents in areas with competitive elections due to higher estimates of likelihood of local fraud. - Hrace: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the respondent’s race/ethnicity. o Difference in likelihood of fraud across treatments will vary with different race/ethnicity due to differential exposure to news media and other discussions of voter fraud o Test with race as defined in covariates below o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation - Heduc: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the respondent’s education. o Difference in likelihood of fraud across treatments will vary with different education level due to differential exposure to news media and other discussions of voter fraud o Test with education as defined in covariates below o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hballot_confid: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the respondent’s confidence in whether ballots are cast as counted. o Test with confidence in institutions at four levels: self (RCO310), local (RCO311), state (RCO312), national (RCO313) o One tailed hypotheses: ▪ Difference in likelihood of fraud between treatments will be smaller for respondents with higher confidence cast as counted at each level due to convergence towards “very unlikely” for both treatments. ▪ Difference in likelihood of fraud between treatments will be larger for individuals with greater difference in confidence between national and (state | local | own ballot) cast as counted (RCO313-(RCO312 | 311 | 310)). - Hinstit_confid: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the respondent’s confidence in government institutions. o Test with confidence in institutions at three levels: national (RCO301); state (RCO302) and local (Local Government GPA, see covariate details); plus difference between national and state (RCO301-RCO302) o One tailed hypotheses: ▪ Difference in likelihood of fraud between treatments will be smaller for respondents with higher confidence in institutions at each level due to convergence towards “very unlikely” for both treatments. ▪ Difference in likelihood of fraud between treatments will be larger for individuals with greater difference in confidence between national and state institutions (RCO301-RCO302). - H2018_vote: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the respondent’s voting behavior in 2018. o Citizens experience with voter registration, mail ballots, early voting, and Election Day voting may influence response to treatments. o Decision to participate in voting may be correlated with perception of voter fraud locally and/or nationally. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - H2016_vote: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on whether the respondent reports having voted in the 2016 election. o Citizens experience with voter registration, mail ballots, early voting, and Election Day voting may influence response to treatments. o Decision to participate in voting may be correlated with perception of voter fraud locally and/or nationally. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hvote_meth: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the voting methods available in respondent’s state. o Citizens experience with mail ballots, early voting, and Election Day voting may influence response to treatments. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hvote_reg: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the voter registration methods available in respondent’s state. o Citizens experience with EDR, OVR, and AVR may influence response to treatments. ▪ Especially “Someone being improperly denied the chance to vote” and “Someone using a false identity to vote illegally” o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hvote_mach: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the type of voting machine(s) used in respondent’s state. o Citizens experience with paper ballots, DRE, and VVPATs will influence perception of vulnerability to voter fraud. ▪ Especially “Cheating in the counting of votes” and “Voting machines failing to record votes correctly” o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - HEPI: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on the quality of election administration in the respondent’s state. o Different aggregate experience with and perception of state election administration will lead to different estimation of local occurrence of voter fraud, and therefore change the difference between the treatments. o Continuous measure using EPI – linear fit o One tailed hypothesis: States with better EPI will have a larger difference than states with poor EPI. - Hofficials: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on respondent’s preference for selection method for local election officials. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation - Hengage: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on respondent’s engagement in political activities. o Define high/low at median observed value o Citizens with different levels of engagement will have different perceptions of occurrence of voter fraud. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation ▪ It is plausible (and hopeful) that more engagement would be correlated with a smaller difference, especially due to convergence that fraud is unlikely both nationally and locally. For some types of voters engagement might be correlated with a smaller difference due to convergence at high likelihood both nationally and locally. However, more engagement might be correlated with a larger difference between treatments as greater experience reduces local likelihood but does not change (or even increases) national likelihood. - Hknowledge: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on respondent’s factual knowledge about politics. o Define high/low at median observed value o Citizens with different levels of factual knowledge will have different perceptions of occurrence of voter fraud. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation ▪ It is plausible (and hopeful) that more factual knowledge would be correlated with a smaller difference, especially due to convergence that fraud is unlikely both nationally and locally. For some types of voters factual knowledge might be correlated with a smaller difference due to convergence at high likelihood both nationally and locally. However, more factual knowledge might be correlated with a larger difference between treatments as greater experience reduces local likelihood but does not change (or even increases) national likelihood. - Hnews_int: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on respondent’s self-reported level of interest in political news. o Define high/low at median observed value o Citizens with different levels of interest in political news will have different perceptions of occurrence of voter fraud. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation ▪ It is plausible (and hopeful) that greater interest in political news would be correlated with a smaller difference, especially due to convergence that fraud is unlikely both nationally and locally. For some types of voters greater interest in political news might be correlated with a smaller difference due to convergence at high likelihood both nationally and locally. However, greater interest in political news might be correlated with a larger difference between treatments as greater experience reduces local likelihood but does not change (or even increases) national likelihood. - Hmode: The difference between “the area where you live” and “somewhere in the country” will vary conditional on whether the respondent takes survey on phone/tablet or computer. o Survey mode influences responses in many ways o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation

q17.value: Outcomes Each of the following survey items will be analyzed to determine if the treatments produce: a) a different distribution of responses across the 4 point scale; b) different proportions of “Very likely” responses; c) different proportions of “Very unlikely”. See appendix for full questions and response scale. 1) Bribery or paying for votes 2) Someone being improperly denied the chance to vote 3) Intimidation at the polling place 4) Cheating in the counting of votes 5) Voting machines failing to record votes correctly 6) Someone using a false identity to vote illegally Analysis: - Regression of each outcome measure on dummies for treatment conditions, with one condition omitted as the reference point since there is no untreated control group in this experiment. o All regressions will also include a series of covariates from the CCES (detailed below). - Change in distribution of responses will be assessed using ordered logit for the 4 point ordered outcome responses scale. o Results will be converted for interpretation with all covariates held at mean values. - Change in proportion of response options at extremes of scale will be assessed using logistic regression. o Results will be converted for interpretation with all covariates held at mean values. - Heterogeneous treatment effects will be tested using interactions of relevant covariates and treatment indicators. - Full assumptions of Rubin-Neyman model of causal inference from randomized experiments. Therefore, use classical hypothesis testing of average treatment effect based robust SEs.

q19.value: N ≅ 1000, less attrition from the pre-election wave to the post-election wave (≅ -100)

q3.value: In this study, we will test whether effort is simultaneously being discounted and valued.

q4.value:
H1a: Effort level relates to choice in a demand selection task, so that the more effortful option is less likely selected the more effort it requires.
H1b: Reward level relates to choice in a demand selection task, so that the more effortful option is more likely selected the more it is rewarded.
H2: Effort level relates to choice in a reward gambling task, so that the less risky option is more likely selected the higher the effort level in the demand selection task.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Within-subject design (treatment: four effort levels, four reward levels) with repeated measures of demand selection choice, self-reported effort and happiness, and reward gambling choice.

q9.value: By combining four effort levels and four reward levels, we have a total of 16 different demand selection choices. Each participant will be presented with each choice three times, resulting in 48 choices in randomized order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit students from University of Toronto via the university’s online recruitment system (SONA). They will be compensated by course credit and can earn additional $ via the demand selection task.

q13.value: We will stop collecting data after we have collected data from 150 participants. Each participant will complete 48 trials.

q14.value: We ran a power simulation using the simr package in R. As input to the simulation we used the data from a previous study. As the previous study did not include the reward gambling task, we simulated this data assuming an effect that the probability to choose the less risky option increases by 10% per effort level. We then went on to simulate power for the increase in one effort level rather than the maximal difference between the highest and lowest effort level. We did this to stay on the conservative side. According to this simulation, we would achieve power = .96 with N = 123. In order to account for the possibility that the manipulation and hence the effect will be slightly weaker, we will aim for 150 participants.

question.value: In the initial demand selection task, participants will repeatedly choose between a baseline offer requiring little cognitive effort for a small reward (i.e., add-1 for 1 credit) and an alternative offer requiring more effort for higher reward (i.e., add-7 for 10 credits). While the baseline offer is always the same, the alternative consists of 4 different effort levels (add-1, add-3, add-5, add-7) and 4 different reward levels (2 credits, 4 credits, 6 credits, 10 credits).

Demand selection choice: Participants will be asked repeatedly (48 times) whether they would like to perform an easier version of the math task for a small reward or a more difficult version for a larger reward.

Self-reported effort: Participants will be asked repeatedly (24 times) how much effort the past five iterations of the task required on a visual analogue scale ranging from ‘none at all’ to ‘very much’. Their responses will be stored as a score ranging from 1 to 100.

Self-reported happiness with reward: Participants will be asked repeatedly (24 times) how happy they are with the rewards they received for the past five iterations of the task on a visual analogue scale ranging from ‘none at all’ to ‘very much’. Their responses will be stored as a score ranging from 1 to 100.

Reward gambling choice: Participants will be asked repeatedly (48 times) whether they would like to gamble with the rewards they just received (meaning they have a 50% chance of doubling the reward / 50% chance of losing the reward) or whether they would like to simply keep the rewards earned.

We will test our hypotheses with a mixed-effects modeling approach (using R and lme4). A maximal-random-effects structure will be used, following Barr, Levy, Scheepers, & Tily (2013). Maximal mixed-effects models frequently run into errors or problems with convergence. If that happens, we will follow the recommendations of Barr et al. (2013, J. Memory and Language) on how to simplify the model. 

We will test the effect of both the effort and reward manipulation on the demand selection choice. As indicated above, we predict both main effects to be significant (negative effect of effort and positive effect of reward on the probability to choose for the alternative offer).

Model syntax for H1a & H1b:

glmer(demandSelectionChoice ~ effortL + rewardL + (1 + effortL + rewardL | pp), data = paradoxData, family = binomial)

We will also test the effect of the effort manipulation on the reward gambling choice. Because the reward manipulation is likely to simultaneously influence this choice, we will control for reward level in this analysis. We predict a negative effect of effort on the probability to choose for the risky offer. For this analysis, we will exclude the trials where the participant chose for the easy version of the task.

Model syntax for H2:

glmer(rewardGamblingChoice ~ effortL + rewardL + (1 + effortL + rewardL | pp), data = paradoxData2, family = binomial)

q20.value: We will use sum-to-zero contrasts for the categorical variables.

q21.value: We will compute bootstrapped p-values (two-tailed; α = .05) with the mixed() command from the afex package.

q22.value: We will check our model for large residuals and influential data points using the influence.ME package. If we find problematically influential data points, we will re-run the analysis without these data points, and we will report the results as an additional analysis (this may be in a footnote or in supplementary materials).

q23.value: (Generalized) linear mixed-effects models deal very well with missing data, so no action is required.

q24.value: Secondary to our main analysis, we will explore the effects of the self-report items on the demand selection and gambling choices.

registration_responses.q3: In this study, we will test whether effort is simultaneously being discounted and valued.
registration_responses.q4:
H1a: Effort level relates to choice in a demand selection task, so that the more effortful option is less likely selected the more effort it requires.
H1b: Reward level relates to choice in a demand selection task, so that the more effortful option is more likely selected the more it is rewarded.
H2: Effort level relates to choice in a reward gambling task, so that the less risky option is more likely selected the higher the effort level in the demand selection task.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: By combining four effort levels and four reward levels, we have a total of 16 different demand selection choices. Each participant will be presented with each choice three times, resulting in 48 choices in randomized order.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will stop collecting data after we have collected data from 150 participants. Each participant will complete 48 trials.
registration_responses.q14: We ran a power simulation using the simr package in R. As input to the simulation we used the data from a previous study. As the previous study did not include the reward gambling task, we simulated this data assuming an effect that the probability to choose the less risky option increases by 10% per effort level. We then went on to simulate power for the increase in one effort level rather than the maximal difference between the highest and lowest effort level. We did this to stay on the conservative side. According to this simulation, we would achieve power = .96 with N = 123. In order to account for the possibility that the manipulation and hence the effect will be slightly weaker, we will aim for 150 participants.
registration_responses.q20: We will use sum-to-zero contrasts for the categorical variables.
registration_responses.q21: We will compute bootstrapped p-values (two-tailed; α = .05) with the mixed() command from the afex package.
registration_responses.q22: We will check our model for large residuals and influential data points using the influence.ME package. If we find problematically influential data points, we will re-run the analysis without these data points, and we will report the results as an additional analysis (this may be in a footnote or in supplementary materials).
registration_responses.q23: (Generalized) linear mixed-effects models deal very well with missing data, so no action is required.
registration_responses.q24: Secondary to our main analysis, we will explore the effects of the self-report items on the demand selection and gambling choices.
registration_responses.q8.question: Within-subject design (treatment: four effort levels, four reward levels) with repeated measures of demand selection choice, self-reported effort and happiness, and reward gambling choice.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will recruit students from University of Toronto via the university’s online recruitment system (SONA). They will be compensated by course credit and can earn additional $ via the demand selection task.
registration_responses.q16.question: In the initial demand selection task, participants will repeatedly choose between a baseline offer requiring little cognitive effort for a small reward (i.e., add-1 for 1 credit) and an alternative offer requiring more effort for higher reward (i.e., add-7 for 10 credits). While the baseline offer is always the same, the alternative consists of 4 different effort levels (add-1, add-3, add-5, add-7) and 4 different reward levels (2 credits, 4 credits, 6 credits, 10 credits).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Demand selection choice: Participants will be asked repeatedly (48 times) whether they would like to perform an easier version of the math task for a small reward or a more difficult version for a larger reward.

Self-reported effort: Participants will be asked repeatedly (24 times) how much effort the past five iterations of the task required on a visual analogue scale ranging from ‘none at all’ to ‘very much’. Their responses will be stored as a score ranging from 1 to 100.

Self-reported happiness with reward: Participants will be asked repeatedly (24 times) how happy they are with the rewards they received for the past five iterations of the task on a visual analogue scale ranging from ‘none at all’ to ‘very much’. Their responses will be stored as a score ranging from 1 to 100.

Reward gambling choice: Participants will be asked repeatedly (48 times) whether they would like to gamble with the rewards they just received (meaning they have a 50% chance of doubling the reward / 50% chance of losing the reward) or whether they would like to simply keep the rewards earned.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will test our hypotheses with a mixed-effects modeling approach (using R and lme4). A maximal-random-effects structure will be used, following Barr, Levy, Scheepers, & Tily (2013). Maximal mixed-effects models frequently run into errors or problems with convergence. If that happens, we will follow the recommendations of Barr et al. (2013, J. Memory and Language) on how to simplify the model. 

We will test the effect of both the effort and reward manipulation on the demand selection choice. As indicated above, we predict both main effects to be significant (negative effect of effort and positive effect of reward on the probability to choose for the alternative offer).

Model syntax for H1a & H1b:

glmer(demandSelectionChoice ~ effortL + rewardL + (1 + effortL + rewardL | pp), data = paradoxData, family = binomial)

We will also test the effect of the effort manipulation on the reward gambling choice. Because the reward manipulation is likely to simultaneously influence this choice, we will control for reward level in this analysis. We predict a negative effect of effort on the probability to choose for the risky offer. For this analysis, we will exclude the trials where the participant chose for the easy version of the task.

Model syntax for H2:

glmer(rewardGamblingChoice ~ effortL + rewardL + (1 + effortL + rewardL | pp), data = paradoxData2, family = binomial)

attributes.title: Replication of "What have I just done? Anchoring, self-knowledge, and judgments of recent behavior" (Cheek, Coe-Odess & Schwartz, 2015, JDM, Study 2B)

item1.value:
I am trying to replicate the effect of the influence of numerical, extreme and nonsensical anchors on the judgement of peoples own recent behavior.
The behavior provided was the solving of 22 math problems. After presenting an anchor, the test subjects should estimate how many of the tasks they previously solved correctly. The anchor was extremely high in one condition and extremely low in the other. A standardized mean difference d between these two groups has been calculated and is now to be replicated.

item2.value: Although there is already a lot of research on the anchor effect, according to the original paper, the anchor effect has not yet been examined with regard to the estimation of self-generated behavior. It is therefore interesting to first investigate whether the effect found in the study can be replicated before further research on the anchor effect is carried out in relation to one's own behavior.

item4.value: The interval between -0.34 and 0.56 includes the effect size in the population with 95 percent certainty (calculated from the original data).

item11.value: The original paper describes the procedure very precisely, which I follow as exactly as possible in the replication. Furthermore, sample tasks are described for each type of task in the paper, so that the tasks I have created are of a similar level of difficulty and scope to the original tasks.

item13.value: Anonymous and randomized assignment of the subjects in the online questionnaire, so that I, as the experimenter, do not know who is processing which questionnaire conditions.

item16.value: A power analysis. At least 94 subjects are required to ensure a power of 80% (at Alpha=5% and d=0,52).

item24.value:
Not exactly the same materials and instructions
Different population, different country, no payment

item26.value:
Following the original study I will:
- exclude participants who will not complete the survey 
- exclude participants that answer at least one of the math questions or attention check questions wrong

item27.value:
Following the original study I will 
- compare group means using a t-test for independent samples

item28.value: Replication is successful when a sufficiently large sample has been recruited and the results have been evaluated and interpreted. Replication is also successful if it is not hypothesizing in the sense of the original paper, because an unexpected result also promotes transparent research and knowledge.

attributes.title: Pre-Analysis Plan: The Wall and the Welfare State - How changes in trade interdependency between the U.S. and Mexico affect risk perception and individual social policy preferences

q1.value: Pre-Analysis Plan: The Wall and the Welfare State - How changes in trade interdependency between the U.S. and Mexico affect risk perception and individual social policy preferences

q5.value: This project is part of the CRC 1342 project B03 “International Complementarities in the Development of National Welfare States: The Transatlantic Sphere 1870-2020” funded by the German Research Foundation. , We would like to thank Melina Altamirano, Clara Baues, Paul Beckmann, and Ann-Katrin Schäfer for research assistance. Moreover, we are grateful to Felix Bethke, Gustavo Flores-Macías, Holger Reinermann,, Cassilde Schwartz, Richard Traunmüller, and our colleagues at the CCCP at University of Cologne for helpful comments and suggestions., We also thank Lydia Repke and Angelika Stiegler from GESIS for detailed feedback on item wording and framing and BGC and Leticia Juárez González in particular for helpful advice on the questionnaire.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: We promote the argument that countries’ economic structural interdependence based on trade relationships influence individual preferences for social policy programs. When a central trading partner raises barriers in the form of increased tolls and tariffs it will increase the perception of labor market vulnerability and economic risk. Subsequently, increased risk perception should fuel different demands for different types of social policy reforms. Labor market segmentation into formal and informal workers thereby moderates the impact of risk. Our analysis contains two steps: the impact of changing trade relationships on individual economic risk perception, and, subsequently, the effect of risk on social policy preferences. To investigate the first part of the argument, we use a vignette experiment that primes individuals about hazards of changes in current trade relationships between Mexico and the U.S.. Next, we analyze how risk perception influences social policy preferences and how far different redistribution coalitions arise. As workers embedded in notoriously permeable labor markets not only frequently switch the sector of employment, but also share households with a spouse who works e. g. in the informal sector, social policy preferences cannot be simply derived from income level. Using a conjoint experiment that models the trade-off between different social policies and different degrees of scope, level, and who pays for it, allows to study the effect of increased risk perception and employment sector on policy preferences in a more nuanced way. We study our argument with an experimental survey for the case of Mexico in 2018.

q16.value: Prediction 1 Mexicans who worry about negative economic effects of U.S. trade policy are more likely to feel insecure about their own job situation. Prediction 1.a Mexican informal sector workers who worry about negative economic effects of U.S. trade policy are more likely to feel insecure about their own job situation compared to formal sector workers. Prediction 2 Formal sector workers who are more exposed to economic insecurities are more likely to support a contribution-based than a universal or means-tested social policy. Prediction 3 Informal sector workers who are more exposed to economic insecurities are more likely to support universal than contribution-based or means-tested social policy. Prediction 4 Mexicans who fear to be cut from remittances from relatives in the U.S. are more likely to support an increase in social policy. Prediction 5 Formal sector workers who were informally employed in the past years are more likely to support a universal than a contribution-based or means-tested social policy. Prediction 6 Formal sector workers who expect to lose the job/to work in the informal sector in the near future are more likely to support a universal than a contribution-based or means- tested social policy. Prediction 7 Informal sector workers are more likely to support an increase for a universal social policy if the form of financing is based on contributions from the government increasing taxes from people with higher incomes or based on workers with written contract and the government. Prediction 8 Formal sector workers are more likely to accept an increase of contribution-based social policy if the form of financing is on contributions from the government increasing taxes from people with higher incomes or with contributions from the government with increased taxes. Prediction 9 Formal sector workers who are more exposed to economic insecurities, and share a household with an informal sector worker, are more likely to support a contribution-based than a universal social policy. Prediction 10 Formal sector workers who are more exposed to economic insecurities and share a household with an informal sector worker are more likely to support a universal than contribution-based social policy. Prediction 11 Informal workers who are more exposed to economic insecurities are more likely to support an increase of social benefits for people in need. Prediction 12 Formal workers who are more exposed to economic insecurities are more likely to support a system of social justice in which only those individuals receive benefits who also contribute to it. Prediction 13 Mexicans who are more exposed to re-migration from Mexicans that are coming back from the U.S. are more likely to support an increase in level of [social policy] benefits. Prediction 14 Mexicans who are more exposed to migration from Central America are more likely to support a contribution-based social policy.

q17.value: The experimental survey will be conducted face-to-face (computer-assisted-personal interviewing) through the Mexican survey company BGC (Beltrán, Juárez y Asociados). Instead of a nationally representative survey, which would go beyond our funding capacities and due to difficulties to field the survey in geographic areas dominated by drug cartels, we aim at drawing a random sample of Mexicans in two average federal states, Puebla and Querétaro. Thereby, we focus on selecting two states of Mexico with average values on trade and GDP per capita as this allows to reach the active working population without over- or underestimating a possible impact from changes in trade interdependencies. The survey company will interview roughly 1‘400 individuals in total, therefore around 700 persons per state. The survey consists of two parts: an observational and an experimental section. We employ a vignette experiment to test the first part of the argument regarding the impact of trade related risks on individual vulnerability. Furthermore, we investigate the demand for welfare state programs (universal, contributory or needs-based benefits) with the use of a conjoint experiment.

q23.value: The study was submitted to the ethics board of the University of Cologne but had not yet been reviewed at the time of registration. Confirmation was provided to EGAP on 2/26/18

attributes.title: Humanoid robot-assisted interventions and health outcomes among diabetic children: A systemic scoping review

summary.value:
Background
The incidences of Type 1 Dm has been increasing by 3.4-6% per year in childhood. If diabetic children learn to self-manage at an earlier stage, they may be able to cope better with their condition in the future. Humanoid robots have the potential to augment human care in a way that can provide cost-effective while yielding a highly satisfying and personalized patient experience.

Objectives
This review aimed to elucidate the roles of a humanoid robot in improving diabetic children's management and to identify the health outcomes from humanoid robot-assisted interventions.

Methods
The five-stage Arksey and O'Malley's methodological framework was used for conducting this scoping review: Identifying the research question; Identify relevant studies; Study selection; Charting the data and Collating, summarizing and reporting the results.

A comprehensive search in 10 databases was done from inception to Feb 2020.
Snowball method was performed in reference lists, grey literature, and relevant journals.
Two independent reviewers examined all full articles for fit with the eligibility criteria.
Items of data extraction included characteristics of articles, description of humanoid robot-assisted interventions and mechanism of the humanoid robot in improving diabetic children management.

The review process followed the Preferred Reported Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) reporting guidelines for scoping reviews (PRISMA-ScR).

attributes.title: Workaholism and Work-Family Conflict: A Daily Diary Examination
attributes.description: The purpose of this study is to expand our understanding of how and why workaholism influences time spent with family (i.e. a high rate of work-family conflict) using daily diary study methodology. Using one behavioral (hours worked) and one cognitive (psychological detachment) component, this study will attempt to assess and explain daily variation within this relationship.

q1.value: Workaholism and Work-Family Conflict: A Daily Diary Examination

q2.value: Haley R. Cobb, Candice  L. Thomas, Lauren Murphy, Lexi Hartman

q3.value:
Although it is understood that workaholism (i.e. working obsessively and working compulsively, an over-attachment to work) relates to work-family conflict (WFC), little is known about the mechanisms that underlie this relationship and how this relationship may vary as a result of daily experiences. This study is designed to assess mechanisms and daily variation of the workaholic-WFC relationship. A double-mediation model will examine both behavioral (hours worked) and cognitive (psychological detachment) mechanisms that may explain the relationship. Daily diary study methodology will expand understanding of the daily experiences of strain for these particularly vulnerable employees. 

There are three specific aims within this study: (1) To replicate the positive relationship between workaholism and WFC, (2) To explore possible the behavioral and cognitive mechanisms that explain why workaholism results in WFC; and (3) To determine if the behavioral or cognitive mechanism is a stronger predictor of the known relationship.

q4.value:
H1: There will be a direct effect between workaholism and WFC, such that daily workaholism will be positively related to daily WFC.

H2: There will be an indirect effect of workaholism on WFC through long work hours, such that daily workaholism will be positively related to daily WFC indirectly through long work hours.

H3: There will be an indirect effect of workaholism on WFC through low psychological detachment, such that daily workaholism will be positively related to daily WFC indirectly through low psychological detachment.

Research question 1: We will determine which mechanism, either long work hours or low psychological detachment, will be a greater contributor to the relationship between workaholism and WFC. 

Exploratory analyses: although we do not have formal hypotheses for these, we plan to collect information regarding problem-solving rumination, difficulty relaxing and impatience, and occupational role reward value.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will use daily diary study methodology (also called experience sampling) to assess the mechanisms that explain the workaholism-WFC relationship. It should be noted that prior to the full delivery of the proposed research study, the complete diary study battery will be pilot tested in the research lab to capture programming errors, length of interview time, and grammatical or spelling errors. Pilot testing will occur on cellular phones and laptops that are connected to WIFI, cellular data, or ethernet to ensure that all platforms work properly. 

The study procedure includes one initial survey in order to assess baseline scores and eligibility (i.e. FTE, over 18 years old), plus ten additional diaries for those who volunteer to participate. The diaries will begin on the following Monday and end Friday. Each participant will respond to two diaries per day (afternoon and evening). Thus, our data will be multi-level (days nested within individuals). Our hypotheses will primarily assess within-person variation; however we will also examine between-person variation using responses to the baseline survey and aggregated dairy responses.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This protocol has been approved by the Saint Louis University Institutional Review Board (IRB; Title: "Working Behaviors and Family Life"; Protocol ID: 30938).

As noted in the study design, the initial survey will assess eligibility and baseline scores. For those eligible and willing to participate, data will be collected the following week from Monday until Friday with 10 diaries. Each day will include two diaries (one afternoon, one evening). Participants will be emailed a link from Qualtrics to each diary when they return from work and prior to going to bed. Participants will have the opportunity to indicate their preferred time on the initial survey. For the initial survey, no reimbursement is given; for the diary studies, a total of up to $10 will be awarded in an electronic gift card (i.e. $1 for each completed diary). Data collection efforts will begin in mid-March and will continue until 100 participants have successfully completed the diary-portion of the study. We estimate all data collection efforts will be completed prior to summer 2020.

Participants will be eligible for participation if they are 18 years of age or older and are employed full-time. All participants must have access to the Internet in order to complete the daily diary surveys, and surveys will be hosted by Qualtrics. The daily diary surveys will be accessible by cell phone with Internet connectivity or computers with Internet connectivity. We aim to collect data from around 100 participants. This will account for any attrition or missed collection points. Participants will be recruited online via social media websites (e.g. LinkedIn, Facebook). Additionally, eligibility includes supplying useable data. We will assess usability by: removing cases due to careless responding, checking IP addresses, checking time to completion, non-sensical or inconsistent responses, and missed attention checks. By assessing data quality, we will also eliminate any potential "bots" in the data (i.e. non-human respondents). 

Workaholism will be assessed with the Dutch Work Addiction Scale (DUWAS; Schaufeli, Shimazu, & Taris, 2009). The short form of the DUWAS will be used in order to reduce the participant burden. The DUWAS contains two factors: working excessively and working compulsively. Example items include: “I find myself continuing work after my co-workers have called it quits” (working excessively) and “It’s important for me to work hard even when I don’t enjoy what I’m doing” (working compulsively). All scale items are answered on a Likert-type scale from 1 (almost never) to 5 (almost always). Hypothesis testing will utilize the composite workaholism score in order to operationalize workaholism as a continuous variable, and exploratory analyses will examine the subscales and cutoff score.

Psychological detachment will be used to assess one’s ability to mentally disengage from work during time with family, and we will use of The Recovery Experience Questionnaire (REQ; Sonnentag & Fritz, 2007) to measure psychological detachment. The REQ contains four items that address psychological detachment. An example item includes: “I forget about work.” All items are ranked on a 5-point Likert-type scale ranging from 1 (I do not agree at all) to 5 (I fully agree). The REQ shows good psychometric validity (Sonnentag & Fritz, 2007).
 
The Work-Family Conflict Scale (Netemeyer, Boles, & McMurrian, 1996) will be used to assess WFC. An example item includes: “The demands of my work interfere with my home and family life.” The original scale contains five items that are ranked on a 7-point Likert-type scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree); we will use a 5-point Likert-type scale in order to maintain consistency across scales in our survey. This study will also use a shortened, four item scale that is a better fit for the models and shows good psychometric validity (Boyar, Carson, Mosley Jr., Maertz Jr., & Pearson, 2006). Deleting the original fourth item (“My job produces strain that makes it difficult to fulfill my family duties”) has been shown to reduce error and explain more variance.

The survey will contain open ended responses for participants to indicate when they got home from work, if they intend to work any more that evening, and how many total hours they worked.

For the purposes of this study, all scale items will be altered so that participants can answer them in the context of the current workday and will be answered in the context of since their prior diary entry. For example, a questionnaire item may be prompted, “Since you last responded to this diary” and the question will be read as “I found myself continuing work after my co-workers have called it quits.” Additionally, all questions will be answered at each time points.

question.value:
Predictor: We will measure workaholism using the DUWAS (Schaufeli, Shimazu, & Taris, 2009). This allows us to measure workaholism as a continuous variable. Workaholism is defined as a feeling of needing to engage in work behaviors beyond what is necessary and thinking obsessively about work (Clark et al., 2016).
Mediators: Hours worked refers to the amount of hours each participant worked formally plus informally each day. Hours worked is assessed with open ended responses. Psychological detachment refers to ones ability to remove their mental thoughts from work and will be assessed with the REQ (Sonnentag & Fritz, 2007).
Criterion: Work-family conflict (WFC) refers to the strain experience when one's work role interferes with successful fulfillment of one's family role (Greenhaus & Beutell, 1985) and will be measured with the Work-Family Conflict Scale by Netemeyer and colleagues (1996).

Exploratory analyses:
Occupational role reward value refers to one's general beliefs regarding their job and will be assessed with the occupational role reward value subscale on the Life Role Salience Scale (LRSS; Amatea, Cross, Clark, & Bobby, 1986).
Problem-solving rumination, or pondering, refers to one's work-related rumination that is distinctly focused on how to address issues at work (Questret & Cropley, 2012). Problem-solving rumination occurs after work when an individual continues to mentally engage in thoughts about solving problems in the work context. This will be measured with the Problem-Solving Rumination Subscale of the Work-Related Rumination Questionnaire (WRRQ; Cropley, Michialianou, Pravettoni, & Millward, 2012).
We aim to measure psychological distress, meaning a negative emotional state. To measure psychological distress, we are using two sub scales of the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (DASS; Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995): Difficulty Relaxing and Impatient.

Prior to hypothesis testing, we will assess the reliability of our scales by assessing Cronbach’s alpha(α) and Macdonald’s omega total (ωtotal) for each scale. Once sufficient reliability is established, we will conduct confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) to address common method bias concerns and to check that each measured variable represents different constructs. Lastly, we will conduct analyses to ensure that any missing data are missing at random; any missing data should not be systematically related to high levels of workaholism or WFC so that we have equal representation of the range of each variable assessed. We expect to have some missing data and will not exclude cases based on missing diary entries. Only cases with fewer than three diary entries will be removed from subsequent data analyses. This is to ensure that each case has at least three diary entries so that we can establish the temporal precedence of our hypothesized causal relationships . Additionally, we will conduct analyses to assess for normality, outliers, and missing data, and we will analyze basic descriptive statistics and create visualizations of data distributions.

Our data will consist of days (level 1) nested within persons (level 2). Person-data (e.g., gender, number of children, telecommuting, and job experience level) will be measured with the baseline survey and will be modeled at level 2. Day-level data (e.g., workaholism, WFC, work hours, psychological detachment) will be measured with the twice-daily diary entries and will be modeled at level 1. Due to the nested nature of diary study data, we will use hierarchical linear modeling to test our hypotheses. 

Our hypotheses do not suggest any time-related relationships (e.g. rates of workaholism are not expected to increase as the week progresses). Because of this, both within- and between-person models can be used to examine the hypotheses. Prior to assessing our hypotheses, we will first check to ensure that hierarchical linear modeling is appropriate for the data by calculating the within-individual and between-individual variance accounted for by our study variables. If a meaningful proportion of variance is accounted for by the within-persons variance, then we will proceed with within-person analyses. If a low proportion of the variance is accounted for by the within-persons variance, we will utilize between-person analyses. 

Ideally, we will assess our hypotheses using a within-person model. For this, hypothesis testing and exploratory analyses will primarily occur at level 1 (within-person), where i represents each data point per participant and j represents each participant, and all hypothesized level-1 variables will be group-mean centered (i.e. person-centered). Level-2 covariates (i.e. gender, number of children, telecommuting, and job experience level) will be measured during the baseline survey, represent between-person constructs, and will be grand-mean centered. Because we are assessing all day-level variables at both afternoon and evening time points, we are also able to include previous measurements of the hypothesized variables as level-1 covariates in the model.  In addition to the hypothesized models, an intercepts-only model (null model) will be tested. Hypothesis 1 tests the direct effect of our model: the relationship between workaholism on WFC. Hypotheses 2 and 3, the indirect effects of our model, assess the influence of our hypothesized mediators (i.e. hours worked and psychological detachment) on the relationship between workaholism and WFC. Once we have determined the direct and indirect effects, we will determine which mediator has a greater impact on the workaholism-WFC relationship. We will obtain 95% confidence intervals using bootstrapping procedures for 10,000 simulations. Analyses for hypothesis testing will be conducted in R using the lavaan package (Rosseel, 2019). 

If our data does not support within-person model assessment, we will assess the hypotheses using between-person models. For this, we will use an aggregate value of the responses across all measurement time periods. The model testing will include the same three hypothesized models as listed above (just at the between-person level). All variables with a between-person model will be grand-mean centered.   

We carefully screen data from the baseline survey in order to maintain high data quality. Due to the high prevalence of bots (i.e. non-human respondents) and the likelihood of careless responding, we will adhering to strict data quality management. For example, any participant that provides bogus data, data that are inconsistent, or are otherwise deemed not usable will be excluded from data analyses, and these participants will not be invited to participate in the diary-portion of the study.

q20.value: Level 1 variables (e.g., workaholism, WFC) will be person-centered , and level 2 variables (e.g., gender, number of children) will be grand mean-centered. Unless preliminary data analysis suggests a full categorical approach is best, Level 2 variables will also be coded such that any categorical groupings are dichotomous in order to reduce the number of covariates in our model (e.g., telecommuting will be dichotomous such that a participant either telecommutes or does not telecommute). All level 1 variables will be examined as continuous variables. As noted earlier, the DUWAS allows us to examine workaholism as a continuous variable or with cutoff scores; we plan to use the continuous scheme and will refer to cutoff scores if necessary. All continuous variables will be coded so that lower values (i.e. 1, 2) reflect lower scores of the construct (e.g., a mean score of 1 for WFC would refer to low WFC) and higher values (i.e., 4, 5) reflect higher values of the construct (e.g., a mean score of 5 for WFC would refer to high WFC).

q21.value: Significance will be assessed at p<.05 for our hypothesis testing, and confidence intervals will be constructed through 10,000 bootstrapped simulations.

q22.value:
A rigorous data quality management standard is in place for this study. For the baseline survey, participants will be excluded from analyses if they: 1) meet any single immediate exclusionary term (e.g., less than 2 minutes to complete the entire survey; indicate that they did not provide honest answers), or 2) meet two or more exclusionary criteria (e.g., straightening, missing an attention check, providing bogus open ended answers). Once participants are deemed eligible, those in the diary survey will be excluded on the basis of straightening, speeding, or inconsistent responding, for example. 

Hierarchical linear modeling takes missing values into account, thus rendering cases with missing data points useable. However, a participant must have responded to both the afternoon and evening diaries for that one day to be useable data. We consider a diary (or the initial survey) to be "complete" if >70% of the survey is filled out with useable data. Extreme values, such as outliers, will be determined through our tests of normality and examining the distribution prior to hypothesis testing, and will be addressed prior to hypothesis testing.

q23.value: Hierarchical linear modeling takes missing values into account, thus rendering cases with missing data points useable. However, a participant must have responded to both the afternoon and evening diaries for that one day to be useable data. We consider a diary (or the initial survey) to be "complete" if >70% of the survey is filled out with useable data.

q24.value: We will conduct exploratory analyses using our additional variables (e.g., occupational role reward value, problem-solving rumination, difficulty relaxing and impatience) if there are identified problems with our measurement models or if there remains significant unexplained variance in our models. These exploratory variables will be examined as additional pieces of our models, due to their conceptual similarity with our primary variables (i.e. workaholism, WFC, etc). Any exploratory analyses will follow the same procedure as described for our main hypotheses.

registration_responses.q1: Workaholism and Work-Family Conflict: A Daily Diary Examination
registration_responses.q2: Haley R. Cobb, Candice  L. Thomas, Lauren Murphy, Lexi Hartman
registration_responses.q3:
Although it is understood that workaholism (i.e. working obsessively and working compulsively, an over-attachment to work) relates to work-family conflict (WFC), little is known about the mechanisms that underlie this relationship and how this relationship may vary as a result of daily experiences. This study is designed to assess mechanisms and daily variation of the workaholic-WFC relationship. A double-mediation model will examine both behavioral (hours worked) and cognitive (psychological detachment) mechanisms that may explain the relationship. Daily diary study methodology will expand understanding of the daily experiences of strain for these particularly vulnerable employees. 

There are three specific aims within this study: (1) To replicate the positive relationship between workaholism and WFC, (2) To explore possible the behavioral and cognitive mechanisms that explain why workaholism results in WFC; and (3) To determine if the behavioral or cognitive mechanism is a stronger predictor of the known relationship.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: There will be a direct effect between workaholism and WFC, such that daily workaholism will be positively related to daily WFC.

H2: There will be an indirect effect of workaholism on WFC through long work hours, such that daily workaholism will be positively related to daily WFC indirectly through long work hours.

H3: There will be an indirect effect of workaholism on WFC through low psychological detachment, such that daily workaholism will be positively related to daily WFC indirectly through low psychological detachment.

Research question 1: We will determine which mechanism, either long work hours or low psychological detachment, will be a greater contributor to the relationship between workaholism and WFC. 

Exploratory analyses: although we do not have formal hypotheses for these, we plan to collect information regarding problem-solving rumination, difficulty relaxing and impatience, and occupational role reward value.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question:
We will use daily diary study methodology (also called experience sampling) to assess the mechanisms that explain the workaholism-WFC relationship. It should be noted that prior to the full delivery of the proposed research study, the complete diary study battery will be pilot tested in the research lab to capture programming errors, length of interview time, and grammatical or spelling errors. Pilot testing will occur on cellular phones and laptops that are connected to WIFI, cellular data, or ethernet to ensure that all platforms work properly. 

The study procedure includes one initial survey in order to assess baseline scores and eligibility (i.e. FTE, over 18 years old), plus ten additional diaries for those who volunteer to participate. The diaries will begin on the following Monday and end Friday. Each participant will respond to two diaries per day (afternoon and evening). Thus, our data will be multi-level (days nested within individuals). Our hypotheses will primarily assess within-person variation; however we will also examine between-person variation using responses to the baseline survey and aggregated dairy responses.

This protocol has been approved by the Saint Louis University Institutional Review Board (IRB; Title: "Working Behaviors and Family Life"; Protocol ID: 30938).

attributes.title: The Influence of Psychopathy on State Anxiety and Beat-to-Beat Cardiovascular Reactivity to Emotional and Cognitive Stressors

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
The Influence of Psychopathy on State Anxiety and Beat-to-Beat Cardiovascular Reactivity to Emotional and Cognitive Stressors.
The purpose of this project is to examine the effects that psychopathy may have on stress responses; in terms of cardiovascular reactivity and self-reported state anxiety in response to a cognitively stressful task and an emotionally stressful task. The study is interested in investigating whether the presence of mild levels of psychopathic traits may be advantageous in some ways, for example by reducing the levels of stress that people with psychopathic traits might experience when confronted with a stressful situation.

other.value: Another motivation for the current study is that a large majority of research is conducted on males, so more research is needed using mixed gender samples. For example, a study found that male psychopaths lacked any stress induced increases in cortisol during the Tier Social Stress Test, whereas the same effect was not reported in female psychopaths. Therefore, this means cortisol levels may be a gender specific marker for psychopathic personality traits (O’Leary et al 2007).  As a secondary analysis; Gender Differences will be examined.

sample.value: A sample size of 34 participants is required to observe medium effects size at 0.8 power and an alpha level of 0.05. Therefore, 40 participants will be recruited to allow for any dropouts and/or missing data that could occur during the investigation.

analyses.value:
For each of the cardiovascular parameters (heart rate variability, heart rate, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, stroke volume, cardiac output and total peripheral resistance), the value obtained for each heart beat will be summed and divided by the total number of heartbeats during the i) baseline period, ii) cognitive stressor and iii) emotional stressor. The baseline averages will be subtracted from the average for each stressor to obtain a ‘change from baseline’ value for each stressor. These will serve as the DVs. Similarly, change from baseline scores for state anxiety will be obtained by subtracting the state anxiety score obtained immediately following each stressor from the baseline state anxiety score.
To analyse the data, a 2x2 mixed ANOVA will be run for each DV: Stressor  (cognitive stressor, emotional stressor) x Psychopathy scores (low, high). Stressor is a within subjects factor and psychopathy score is a between-subjects factor.
As a secondary exploratory analysis; Gender Differences will be examined by adding gender as a factor into the mixed ANOVAs. These exploratory analyses will be analysed by a Stressor  (cognitive stressor, emotional stressor) x Psychopathy scores (low, high) X gender (male, female) mixed ANOVA for each DV.

outliers.value:
In order to reduce any ethical implications, the exclusion criteria are that participants must be over 18 years of age, not have any history of mental health disorder, high blood pressure or any existing heart conditions.
Extreme outliers (change scores in beat-to-beat cardiovascular measures for any of the DVs > 3 SD from the mean) will be excluded from the analyses.

dependent.value:
The dependent variables being measured for this study are subjective stress response, which will be measured using the state portion of the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (Spielberger, 1983). 
Beat-to-Beat Cardiovascular reactivity will also be measured to investigate physiological stress response. This technique allows us to explore heart rate variability (the SD of each individual’s interbeat interval), heart rate, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, stroke volume, cardiac output and total peripheral resistance.

conditions.value:
Based on participants’ scores from the Levenson Self-Report Psychopathy Scale (LSRP; Levenson et al, 1995), a median score will be calculated. From this, participants will be placed into the low psychopathy group if their scores deviates below the median, or the high psychopathy group if they score higher than the median. Participants with scores that fall on the median will be assigned to the low psychopathy group.
Participants in both the low and high psychopathy groups will be required to take part in two tasks designed to induce stress. 
There will be a cognitive stressor which will involve participants taking part in a short mental arithmetic task. The task will involve participants counting backwards from 3921 in multiples of 9, for five minutes. If they get the answers wrong, they will be told to start again from the beginning.
Participants will also take part in an emotional stressor task. This will involve participants being exposed to fifteen high arousal, low valence images from the International Affective Picture System (IAPS; 2008). Participants will be told the details of this task in the information sheet in which they will be advised not to take part if they feel this will cause them extreme discomfort. Fifteen images will be shown to the participant for 20 seconds each. To ensure engagement with the task, participants will be required to rate, on a 10 point scale, how unpleasant they find each image. 
The order of the stressors will be counterbalanced. Prior to administration of the stressors, a five-minute baseline cardiovascular recording will be obtained. A five-minute recovery period will be incorporated between each stressor.

hypothesis.value:
Psychopathic Disorder is described as a ‘persistent disorder or disability of the mind (whether or not including significant impairment of intelligence), which results in abnormally high aggression or seriously irresponsible conduct’ (HMSO, 1983), and psychopathy is most commonly characterised by a lack of emotion and empathy. 
Due to media stereotypes, there is a negative stigma of psychopathy due to films, for example, portraying psychopaths as dangerous villains with no emotion or moral compass. Where this may be true in some cases of psychopathy, only 15-25% of the prison population are categorised as psychopaths (Kirkman,2002), meaning psychopathy cannot be the only valid explanation for violent or criminal behaviour. One per cent of the general population meet the criteria for psychopathy but given that these individuals are able to live a functional life in society, they are likely free of criminality and are able to abide to social norms. 
This study aims to question the stigma around psychopathy and investigate if some aspects of psychopathy are actually advantageous. For example, there is research that has discussed ‘successful psychopaths’ which refer to those who have no criminal record and have excelled in their careers, for example there is evidence for a high proportion of psychopathy in occupations such as law, the cooperate world and politics (Cleckley 1988, Hare 2003). A common trait in psychopathy is fearlessness and risk taking, which in business can pay off and lead to huge financial benefits. The current investigation will focus on dealing with stress, as there is evidence that those who display psychopathy demonstrate differences in physiological and subjective responses to stress. For example, those classed as high psychopathy in a sample of 48 incarcerated males had the lowest scores on Stanford Acute Stress reactivity questionnaire (Pham 2012). Further, in terms of physiological reactions, urine, adrenaline and noradrenaline were measured in 24 male prisoners 2 weeks, 1 week and directly before their trial (Lidberg et al 1978). High psychopathy was linked to no increase in adrenaline or noradrenaline immediately before the trial, which is seemingly the most stressful timepoint. 
A large majority of research into psychopathy is conducted with incarcerated population when investigating the effects of psychopathic traits and stress. Most people only get a diagnosis of psychopathy once they have been admitted to prison or the forensics ward, meaning that many individuals living in the general population could exhibit psychopathic traits without having been formally assessed for psychopathy. We have a lack of knowledge about how psychopathic traits, among the non-incarcerated population, may be advantageous or detrimental in everyday life. Therefore, in the current study, we will administer a measure of psychopathic traits to members of the general population and measure their stress response using a subjective State Anxiety Inventory, as well as a physiological stress response by measuring beat to beat cardiovascular reactivity.
 There is also evidence for some autonomic nervous system irregularities. Individuals with psychopathic personality traits exhibit a blunted startle response and electrodermal activity when exposed to experimental stressors like loud noise blasts (O’Leary et al 2007).  Therefore, this study will investigate another marker of autonomic dysregulation by measuring heart rate variability to investigate potential effects of psychopathic personality traits on autonomic function, in response to stress.
Based on the existing literature, we expect to find lower beat-to-beat cardiovascular reactivity (e.g. heart rate and blood pressure responses to stress), indicative of blunted cardiovascular reactivity, in those who report psychopathic traits. As well as this, we also expect to find lower state anxiety ratings in response to the emotional and cognitive stressors in the participants who report psychopathic traits.
